items.field_deck: The design of products, devices, services, or environments for people with disabilities
items.field_summary: Accessibility isn’t just the right thing to do; it’s the law. The guidance, resources, and community you find here will help you deliver accessible digital products and services in the federal government.
items.legislation_title: Section 508 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973

field_featured_links.title: Federal website standards
field_featured_links.summary: The federal website standards help agencies provide high-quality, consistent digital experiences for everyone. They cover common visual technical elements and reflect user experience best practices.

field_featured_links.title: Section508.gov
field_featured_links.summary: This site provides guidance for federal agencies on several topics in IT accessibility, including creating accessible websites and documents, accessibility testing, accessibility training, and accessibility in contracting and procurement.

field_featured_links.title: Best practices for writing for the accessible web
field_featured_links.summary: Tips for making online information accessible for those with auditory and visual needs.

field_featured_links.title: An advanced approach to accessibility
field_featured_links.summary: Accessibility is one of the most important values underlying all the work that we do. This is a deeper look into accessibility: what to do, how to do it, and why it matters, especially in government.

field_featured_links.title: Accessibility: Usability for every ability
field_featured_links.summary: Incorporate accessibility from the start and celebrate accessibility guidelines that help build better products and services for all users.

field_featured_links.title: Accessibility for Teams
field_featured_links.summary: A quick-start guide for embedding accessibility and inclusive design practices into your team’s workflow.

items.field_deck: Learn about how to acquire supplies and services.
items.field_summary: Federal acquisition is governed by a complex web of laws, regulations, and policies. It can lead to the selection of qualified vendors who deliver the best value for the government and the public — reducing risk and wasteful spending, and improving outcomes for the public.
items.legislation_title: Federal Acquisition Regulation

items.field_deck: Measure and plan your site performance with analytics best practices and tools
items.field_summary: Web analytics provide valuable insights into how users interact with a website. Use the data gained from web analytics to identify areas for improvement and make data-driven decisions. This can lead to a more user-friendly and engaging website, which can enhance trust and overall site performance.
items.legislation_title: Executive Order 14058 and OMB Circular A-11 Section 280

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to analytics
field_featured_links.summary: Learn how to set performance goals, and identify specific KPIs and targets to measure and meet them, using web analytics.

field_featured_links.title: How to build an analytics strategy
field_featured_links.summary: The Digital Analytics Program (DAP) provides a start-to-finish approach for assessing, reporting, and taking action using Digital.gov in a case study.

field_featured_links.title: Video: Continuously improve your website by using customer feedback and web analytics: An IRS case study (length: 31:27)
field_featured_links.summary: Learn how you can use web analytics to make improvements to user experience.

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to search
field_featured_links.summary: Follow search engine optimization (SEO) best practices to help search engines discover your content.

field_featured_links.title: How to use web analytics to uncover cybersecurity incidents: A USAGov case study
field_featured_links.summary: Learn how you can take a deep dive into analytics and uncover phishing attempts or other improper use of your agency’s content, logo, or brand.

field_featured_links.title: How to track performance
field_featured_links.summary: Use this step-by-step guide to choose metrics & tools, set budgets & goals, and add site tracking on your website.

items.field_deck: Artificial intelligence involves machines programmed to learn and reason.
items.field_summary: Artificial intelligence (AI) is an emerging technology where machines are programmed to learn, reason, and perform in ways that simulate human intelligence. Although AI technology took a dramatic leap forward, the ability of machines to automate manual tasks has been around for a long time. Today’s AI can analyze vast amounts of data to identify patterns and trends, providing insights to improve decisions in areas like resource allocation and risk management. Follow your agency’s guidance on security and best practices when using AI.
items.legislation_title: Executive Order on Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Artificial Intelligence
items.featured_resource_summary: Ensuring the U.S. leads in safe, secure, and trustworthy artificial intelligence innovation to harness the opportunities of AI while mitigating its risks.

items.field_deck: Ideas and resources for delivering better digital experiences
items.field_summary: Best practices can help jumpstart digital service delivery efforts. Agencies and teams across the federal government frequently share resources, case studies, and learnings that other practitioners can put into practice. Using best practices contributes to less guesswork and streamlined, consistent experiences for users.
items.legislation_title: Requirements for delivering a digital-first public experience

field_featured_links.title: Timeless top 10 best practice for great government websites
field_featured_links.summary: Explore fundamental best practices for delivering federal websites and digital services.

field_featured_links.title: Federal website standards
field_featured_links.summary: The federal website standards help agencies provide high-quality, consistent digital experiences for everyone. They cover common visual technical elements and reflect user experience best practices.

field_featured_links.title: Use the U.S. Web Design System Maturity Model
field_featured_links.summary: Understand how to adopt the design system incrementally and build better digital experiences.

field_featured_links.title: Understanding the Digital Analytics Program
field_featured_links.summary: The Digital Analytics Program (DAP) offers advanced, easy web analytics for federal agencies. All public-facing federal websites can participate.

items.field_summary: For federal agencies, budgeting and performance are linked by a framework that guides them in setting priorities and measuring progress. Agencies need to develop strategic objectives and performance measures so that they can track progress and demonstrate effectiveness. Performance data should be used by agencies to inform budget decisions, to ensire that resources are directed towards activities with the highest impact on achieving stated goals.
items.legislation_title: The President’s Management Agenda

items.field_deck: Prize competitions can advance the missions of federal agencies.
items.field_summary: Agencies can use prize competitions to connect with the public braintrust, tapping into diverse expertise and perspectives to solve complex problems. Prize competitions often lead to unconventional and efficient solutions that might not be found within traditional government structures. Agencies and the public benefit from fresh approaches to tackle challenges in areas like healthcare, cybersecurity, and environmental protection.
items.legislation_title: American Innovation and Competitiveness Act (Public Law 114-329)
items.featured_resource_summary: Where competition delivers innovation for the public good.

items.field_deck: Digital infrastructure means hardware and software. It Includes physical and virtual “cloud” storage spaces.
items.field_summary: Digital infrastructure includes hardware and software components that build the foundation of information technology systems. When you save a file online instead of on your own computer, you’re saving it virtually in “the cloud.” The cloud is a network of remote servers, storage, databases, and other resources accessed over the internet, rather than being maintained onsite in a physical data center.
items.legislation_title: Circular No. A-130 - Managing Information as a Strategic Resource
items.featured_resource_title: Cloud Smart: Federal Cloud Computing Strategy
items.featured_resource_summary: A long-term, high-level strategy to drive cloud adoption in federal agencies. It offers a path forward for agencies to migrate to a safe and secure cloud infrastructure — supporting agencies to achieve additional savings, better security, and faster delivery of services.

items.field_deck: Good written and verbal communications make the government more effective and trustworthy.
items.field_summary: Communicating with the public requires content that’s accurate, relevant, easy-to-use, and conveyed in plain language. Maximize the quality and integrity of information provided to the public by staying informed, connecting with other federal communicators, and implementing best practices shared by trusted resources.
items.legislation_title: Information Quality Act & OMB Memo M-19-15 (PDF, 991 KB, 11 pages)

items.field_deck: Government contact centers are centralized hubs for the public to access information, request services, and receive assistance.
items.field_summary: Contact centers provide a centralized point of access, consolidating diverse services and information under one umbrella. This alleviates the burden on the public to navigate complex organizational structures to reach the agency they need. By streamlining access, contact centers empower individuals to engage with government services effectively, fostering a sense of ease and trust.
items.legislation_title: OMB Circular A-11 Section 280, Managing Customer Experience and Improving Service Delivery

items.field_deck: Make use of content strategy to deliver great digital experiences.
items.field_summary: Content strategy involves planning, creating, delivering, and governing content that meets the needs of its users and achieves an organization’s goals. Content strategy is an essential element of effective digital web services and communication for government agencies.
items.legislation_title: 21st Century IDEA & M-23-22

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to structured content
field_featured_links.summary: Learn how to transform how people find, understand, share, use, and reuse government information.

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to trust
field_featured_links.summary: Learn how to create websites that people trust.

field_featured_links.title: Introduction to translation technology
field_featured_links.summary: Learn how and why to use translation technology to create multilingual content.

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to plain language
field_featured_links.summary: Create communication that is clear and easy to understand for your target audience.

field_featured_links.title: Writing for the accessible web
field_featured_links.summary: Learn how to write and design web content that is accessible for everyone.

items.field_deck: Crowdsourcing and citizen science can accelerate discovery across the U.S. government.
items.field_summary: Through citizen science and crowdsourcing, the federal government and nongovernmental organizations can engage the public in addressing societal needs and accelerating science, technology, and innovation. In citizen science, the public voluntarily participates in the scientific process, addressing real-world problems in ways that may include formulating research questions, conducting scientific experiments, collecting and analyzing data, interpreting results, making new discoveries, developing technologies and applications, and solving complex problems. In crowdsourcing, organizations submit an open call for voluntary assistance from a large group of individuals for online, distributed problem solving.
items.legislation_title: Crowdsourcing and Citizen Science Act of 2016
items.featured_resource_summary: An official government website designed to accelerate the use of crowdsourcing and citizen science across the U.S. government.

items.field_deck: Improving customer experience drives better results in the federal government
items.field_summary: Customer experience (CX) is the sum of the public’s interactions with any government service. An intentional CX strategy is essential to building and maintaining public trust, improving the efficiency and effectiveness of government programs, and delivering better outcomes for the public. By focusing on the customer’s needs and expectations, federal agencies can create more user-friendly and efficient processes, provide more timely and helpful support, and deliver better experiences. This can lead to increased public satisfaction, greater trust in government, and improved outcomes for all.
items.legislation_title: Executive Order on Transforming Federal Customer Experience and Service Delivery to Rebuild Trust in Government

field_featured_links.title: Embed equity in civic design to transform customer experience
field_featured_links.summary: Use lessons learned from this case study, which describes how two civic designers at different agencies embed equity in civic design to transform federal customer experience.

field_featured_links.title: Follow time-tested steps from the VA Customer Experience Cookbook
field_featured_links.summary: The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) Customer Experience Cookbook provides a guide for other government agencies looking to build customer experience capabilities.

field_featured_links.title: Adopt strategies to deliver excellent, equitable, and secure federal services and customer experience
field_featured_links.summary: The second priority of the President’s Management Agenda focuses on revolutionizing the federal government’s customer service delivery and rebuilding the customer experience.

field_featured_links.title: OMB Circular A-11 Section 280 (2023) – Managing Customer Experience and Improving Service (PDF, 385 KB, 14 pages)
field_featured_links.summary: Measure customer experience with this guide from the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), including questions on satisfaction and confidence and trust in section 280.7.

items.field_deck: Make your data more actionable and digestible
items.field_summary: Data visualization helps government teams interpret and communicate information. Visualizations can help simplify complex data, encourage broader interest on a topic, and increase transparency.
items.legislation_title: M-13-13, Guidance on managing open information as an asset

field_featured_links.title: resources.data.gov
field_featured_links.summary: Explore policies, tools, case studies, and other resources supporting the use of data in government.

field_featured_links.title: Involving end users at all stages to create actionable science products for complex, real-world issues
field_featured_links.summary: Understand how to use co-production methods to increase the usefulness of scientific results, products, and tools.

items.field_deck: Understand how and why design impacts user experience
items.field_summary: Guidance, resources, and community to help you use design to create government websites that meet customer needs, work well on any device, and follow federal web requirements.
items.legislation_title: 21st Century Integrated Digital Experience Act

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to federal website standards
field_featured_links.summary: Understand how and why to use the federal website standards. The standards cover common visual technical elements and reflect user experience best practices.

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to design
field_featured_links.summary: How to design government websites that meet customer needs, work well on any device, and follow federal web requirements.

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to design systems
field_featured_links.summary: If your organization needs to ensure compliance with a design standard or align to a brand, a design system can help you achieve those goals more easily than building a site from scratch. Learn how a design system can help you and what you need to know to get started.

field_featured_links.title: USWDS design principles
field_featured_links.summary: Earn trust by following consistent design principles.

field_featured_links.title: Understanding design in 10 questions
field_featured_links.summary: Learn how the discipline of design can help your agency improve customer experience.

field_featured_links.title: Bringing design in-house
field_featured_links.summary: What is design, who are designers, and how can they help your agency? Learn how to build a design team that can help your agency solve “wicked problems” and be more innovative.

items.field_deck: Make it easier for the public to access the information and services that they count on each and every day.
items.field_summary: For millions, access to digital services isn’t a luxury—it’s critical. The public’s experiences using government websites to find unemployment support, file taxes, apply for student loans, or get assistance with housing, childcare, or food can dramatically affect how they feel about the government. Digital service delivery is the primary subject of 21st Century IDEA, and its policy guidance in OMB M-23-22, which requires federal agencies to enact best practices.
items.legislation_title: 21st Century Integrated Digital Experience Act (21st Century IDEA) and M-23-22
items.featured_resource_summary: The federal website standards help agencies provide high-quality, consistent digital experiences for everyone.

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to federal website standards
field_featured_links.summary: Understand how and why to use the federal website standards. The standards cover common visual technical elements and reflect user experience best practices.

field_featured_links.title: Use the U.S. Web Design System maturity model
field_featured_links.summary: Understand how to adopt the Design System incrementally, and design and build better digital experiences.

field_featured_links.title: Participate in the Digital Analytics Program
field_featured_links.summary: The Digital Analytics Program (DAP) offers advanced, easy web analytics for federal agencies. All public-facing federal websites can participate.

field_featured_links.title: Access Site Scanning program data
field_featured_links.summary: The Site Scanning program automates a wide range of scans of public federal websites and generates data about website health, policy compliance, and best practices. Use the data to understand the health of your agency’s websites.

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to digital governance
field_featured_links.summary: Digital governance refers to the internal systems and processes we use to manage our digital presence. Learn why governance is essential to digital service delivery.

field_featured_links.title: Test websites for accessibility
field_featured_links.summary: Design and deliver digital services with everyone in mind. Use both manual and automated testing methods to create accessible websites.

items.field_deck: Find out how to incorporate diversity, equity, inclusion, and accessibility (DEIA) into digital experiences.
items.field_summary: When digital experiences are designed to be inclusive, they are accessible to all — people with diverse abilities, people who speak different languages, and people from diverse cultural, ethnic, and economic backgrounds. Inclusion creates a better user experience for everyone. When we consider inclusion from the start of designing digital experiences, we create a wider impact for the products and services we design.
items.legislation_title: Executive Order 14091: Further Advancing Racial Equity and Support for Underserved Communities Through the Federal Government
items.field_featured_links_title: Diversity, equity, inclusion, and accessibility: Essential knowledge

field_featured_links.title: Embedding equity in civic design to transform customer experience
field_featured_links.summary: Learn how designers in the federal government leverage design methods to build a foundation for improved customer experiences for all people.

field_featured_links.title: Inclusive design patterns
field_featured_links.summary: See the U.S. Web Design System’s research report and learn how findings lead to library of guidance and examples focused on key digital interactions that foster effective, inclusive, and equitable digital experiences.

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to pronouns
field_featured_links.summary: Learn how to respectfully use someone’s pronouns.

field_featured_links.title: Accessibility for Teams
field_featured_links.summary: A quick-start guide for embedding accessibility and inclusive design practices into your team’s workflow.

field_featured_links.title: Office of Personnel Management (OPM) | Diversity, Equity, Inclusion, and Accessibility
field_featured_links.summary: Use these strategies and actions to meet your diversity, equity, and inclusion goals.

items.field_deck: Clear and consistent use of .gov and .mil domains is essential to maintaining public trust.
items.field_summary: It should be easy to identify government websites on the internet. Using a .gov or .mil domain increases security, trust, and accountability, while ensuring the public can clearly identify official government services and information.
items.legislation_title: DOTGOV Act & M-23-10 (PDF, 96 KB, 3 pages, February 2023)
items.featured_resource_summary: .gov is the top-level domain for governments in the U.S. and helps to identify U.S. governments on the internet.

field_featured_links.title: Domain security best practices
field_featured_links.summary: Follow these domain security best practices to ensure a safe experience for your organization and your users.

field_featured_links.title: How to prevent security certificates from expiring during a lapse in operations
field_featured_links.summary: Learn what steps you can take to avoid security certificates from expiring during a lapse in operations.

field_featured_links.title: Building the elements that earn trust
field_featured_links.summary: Government websites with official domain names help build trust with the public.

items.field_deck: Cutting-edge technologies can improve the delivery of public services
items.field_summary: The federal government monitors new technologies, especially those with great potential to change how the public lives and works. Adopting new technologies responsibly can improve the efficiency and quality of government services.
items.legislation_title: Executive Order on the Safe, Secure, and Trustworthy Development and Use of Artificial Intelligence

field_featured_links.title: Administration Actions on AI
field_featured_links.summary: Find updates on the federal government’s work to promote the safe, secure, and trustworthy use of AI. This includes federal agency use cases, the Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights and an AI risk management framework.

field_featured_links.title: Understanding robotic process automation
field_featured_links.summary: Explore how automated technologies can optimize the quality and efficiency of your program services.

field_featured_links.title: Inclusivity and automation: How a bot can help you stay accountable
field_featured_links.summary: Learn how automation can support the development of inclusive language.

field_featured_links.title: Assessing the state of federal robotic process automation
field_featured_links.summary: Learn about the maturity and impact of processing and automation tools across the government.

items.field_deck: Good digital governance leads to better internal team performance as well as better public digital experiences.
items.field_summary: Governance provides a framework for decision-making by establishing standards and procedures and clarifying roles and responsibilities. Digital governance encompasses all aspects of website management and operation, including content, design, technical infrastructure, security, funding, and product, project, and program management.
items.legislation_title: 21st Century IDEA & M-23-22

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to federal website standards
field_featured_links.summary: Understand how and why to use the federal website standards. The standards cover common visual technical elements and reflect user experience best practices.

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to digital governance
field_featured_links.summary: Get an overview of the internal systems and processes used to manage digital presence.

field_featured_links.title: What are agency reporting requirements?
field_featured_links.summary: Learn what the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) requires federal executive agencies to complete by September 2024; one year after M-23-22 issuance.

field_featured_links.title: Who’s on your digital dream team?
field_featured_links.summary: Learn about the various roles your agency could include on your web teams.

field_featured_links.title: Required web content and links
field_featured_links.summary: For executive branch websites, various policies require us to provide certain content, and provide links to content from specific places.

field_featured_links.title: Checklist of requirements for federal websites and digital services
field_featured_links.summary: Learn about high-level policies that cover basic requirements for all websites and digital services.

items.field_deck: Take the guesswork out of service design by understanding people’s needs.
items.field_summary: Human centered design (HCD) is a philosophy and method that places people’s experiences at the heart of service design. Unlike traditional, system-centric approaches, HCD prioritizes understanding real-world challenges and frustrations faced by users and crafting solutions that directly address them. HCD is a continuous process, not a one-time fix. Regular evaluation and user feedback are essential to maintain relevance and adapt services to evolving user needs. HCD provides a valuable framework for ensuring government services are and remain accessible, efficient, and user-centric.
items.legislation_title: 21st Century Integrated Digital Experience Act & OMB Memo M-23-22

items.field_deck: Organizing the information on your website to make it findable, understandable, and usable helps build trust with the public.
items.field_summary: Websites are made up of information—which needs to be organized to be useful. Information architecture (IA), which has roots in physical spaces like libraries and hospitals, should be designed with intention to help people find what they need to know or do. Making sure that search, labeling, appropriate nesting, calls-to-action, and your sitemap are clear and usable is all part of having a functional information architecture.
items.legislation_title: 21st Century Integrated Digital Experience Act & OMB Memo M-23-22

items.field_deck: The process of gathering and documenting data from various sources to fulfill a specific purpose
items.field_summary: Information collection is the first step of many when conducting research and it can involve various methods and technologies. It’s also the process by which federal agencies gather or ask for information about the people who use their services. Collections may require the use of complex forms or sensitive questions, including personally identifiable information. Make sure you follow best practices when collecting information to protect the identity of your users, and to respect their time.
items.legislation_title: Paperwork Reduction Act (44 U.S.C. Chapter 35, PDF, 451 KB, 47 Pages)

items.field_deck: New ideas and methods for improving federal programs and services
items.field_summary: Technology is always evolving. Exploring the latest developments and trends in digital service delivery helps practitioners find new ways to create outstanding digital experiences for users.
items.legislation_title: Open data policy (Memo M-13-13)

field_featured_links.title: Supporting innovation through the American Rescue Plan
field_featured_links.summary: Explore a case study on using ARP funding as a catalyst for long-term resilience

field_featured_links.title: Presidential Innovation Fellows
field_featured_links.summary: Get an overview of a program embedding seasoned technologists and innovators within federal agencies.

field_featured_links.title: Prioritizing equity in government-led innovation programs
field_featured_links.summary: Learn how the Census Open Innovation Labs team supports the next generation of technologists and designers.

items.field_deck: Mobile-friendly government websites improve access and user experience
items.field_summary: People increasingly use their mobile devices to access critical information. Ensuring that government websites work well on mobile devices not only improves the overall user experience but also increases visibility of government services and information. Mobile-friendly federal websites are a part of digital inclusion, transparency, and accountability.
items.legislation_title: Connected Government Act

field_featured_links.title: Eight principles of mobile-friendliness
field_featured_links.summary: Use these eight principles of mobile-friendliness to greatly improve the mobile-friendliness of your websites.

field_featured_links.title: How to make a mobile paper prototype: A USA.gov case study
field_featured_links.summary: Learn how you can use a single piece of paper to make your mobile app work 20 percent better.

field_featured_links.title: Mobile development strategies
field_featured_links.summary: Learn about the most common mobile development strategies.

field_featured_links.title: How to track performance
field_featured_links.summary: A step-by-step guide to picking metrics and tools for tracking performance on your site.

field_featured_links.title: How to contract for mobile development services
field_featured_links.summary: Find out how to structure a Statement of Work (SOW) for the development of mobile products.

items.field_deck: Provide access to government information and services for people with limited English proficiency.
items.field_summary: Demand for multilingual digital content is growing. In response to this demand, federal agencies are publishing more digital content in multiple languages. Expanding digital content in languages other than English is essential to building public trust, effectively serving communities, and ensuring government content is accessible for all.
items.legislation_title: Executive Order 13166, Attorney General memorandum, and Title VI of the Civil Rights Act
items.featured_resource_summary: Find requirements and resources from the Department of Justice on improving access for people with limited English proficiency.

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to multilingual glossaries
field_featured_links.summary: Understand how and why to use a multilingual glossary when translating content.

field_featured_links.title: Top 10 best practices for multilingual websites
field_featured_links.summary: Tips for creating and managing multilingual government websites.

field_featured_links.title: Introduction to translation technology
field_featured_links.summary: Learn how and when to use translation technology to provide meaningful access for people with limited English proficiency.

field_featured_links.title: Select a language: Help a user to choose their preferred language
field_featured_links.summary: U.S. Web Design System technical guidance on how to support users in their language of choice.

field_featured_links.title: Bilingual glossaries, dictionaries, and style guides
field_featured_links.summary: Multilingual resources that improve the way we communicate with people in languages other than English.

items.field_deck: Use a combination of media formats to create impactful experiences.
items.field_summary: As a form of communication, multimedia involves a combination of content forms, like text, audio, video, graphics, and animation. Multimedia approaches work best when they are created and distributed to deliver a well-rounded, interactive, and informative user experience.

items.field_deck: Information that is discoverable and usable by the public
items.field_summary: Open data is information collected by the government and made available to everyone. From information on specific landmarks to statistics on the economy or the environment, availability of open data can drive innovation, efficiency, and value for the public.
items.legislation_title: M-13-13, Guidance on managing open information as an asset

field_featured_links.title: Decoding public sentiment: Harnessing open data to gain insights into service delivery
field_featured_links.summary: Learn how open data can accelerate your customer experience strategy.

field_featured_links.title: How to get your open data on Data.gov
field_featured_links.summary: Find out how federal, federal geospatial, and non-federal data is funneled to Data.gov.

field_featured_links.title: Understanding the Site Scanning program
field_featured_links.summary: This program automatically generates data about the health and best practices of federal websites.

items.field_deck: Deliver transparent, accountable, and trustworthy federal services
items.field_summary: An open government is built on the principles of transparency, participation, and collaboration. Open government initiatives help agencies to be more accountable and responsive to the public.
items.legislation_title: M-10-06, Open Government Directive (PDF, 213 KB, 11 pages)
items.featured_resource_summary: Find information on open government initiatives and progress across the government.

field_featured_links.title: U.S. public participation playbook
field_featured_links.summary: Explore a resource for government managers to effectively evaluate and build better services through public participation

field_featured_links.title: Data.gov
field_featured_links.summary: Visit the U.S. government’s open data site and explore datasets, tools, and other resources.

field_featured_links.title: Challenge.gov
field_featured_links.summary: Learn about Challenge.gov, the official hub for prize competitions across the U.S. federal government.

items.field_summary: Plain language is communication that is clear and easy to understand for your target audience, regardless of the medium used to deliver it. It is communication your audience can understand the first time they encounter it. Using plain language on government websites is one of the best ways to reach your target audience. A clear, concise message builds trust with users because they can understand your call to action and complete their tasks and meet their needs.
items.legislation_title: Plain Writing Act of 2010
items.featured_resource_summary: Plain language makes it easier for the public to read, understand, and use government communications.

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to plain language
field_featured_links.summary: Using plain language is required on all government websites and also creates a better user experience.

field_featured_links.title: Plain language web writing tips
field_featured_links.summary: On the web, people are in a hurry. They skim and scan, looking for fast answers to their questions, so it’s important to get to the point—quickly.

field_featured_links.title: Lessons from the 2021 Federal Plain Language Report Card
field_featured_links.summary: What we learned from examples of web content that received both high and low scores.

field_featured_links.title: OMB Final Guidance on Implementing the Plain Writing Act of 2010 (M-11-15)
field_featured_links.summary: This memorandum provides final guidance on implementing the Act and is designed to promote the goals of the President’s Open Government Initiative.

items.field_deck: Use podcasts to offer pre-recorded content your users can listen to anytime, anywhere.
items.field_summary: Podcasts enable government agencies to connect with the public in a fresh, accessible way. More informal than press releases, podcasts can offer digestible insights into government work. For example, consider demystifying complex policies through engaging interviews, humanizing experts through storytelling, and addressing public concerns in candid conversations. Use podcasts to foster transparency, build trust, and inject a bit of humanity into the public’s perception of government.
The relevant laws, policies, and regulations for federal agencies.

items.field_deck: As agencies carry out their diverse missions, they must also respect and protect personally identifiable information (PII).
items.field_summary: For the public to have trust in government institutions, they need to know that their personal information is secure, and will be used only for legitimate purposes. Privacy violations can put people at risk for identity theft, financial fraud, discrimination, harassment, or even physical harm. By following federal rules and regulations regarding the collection, use, and disclosure of personal information, agencies can mitigate such risks to their customers.
items.legislation_title: Privacy Act of 1974 & various OMB memos

items.field_deck: Acquire new skills and knowledge to improve your career performance and reach your professional goals.
items.field_summary: Ensuring that federal agencies can deliver excellent digital services requires an engaged and well-trained workforce. While core competencies in collaboration, communication, and leadership remain vital, additional skills like data analysis, cybersecurity, and digital fluency are becoming increasingly in-demand. Creating an intentional professional development plan for yourself or your team ensures that we can deliver cutting-edge solutions.
items.legislation_title: The President’s Management Agenda: Workforce Priority

items.field_deck: Work with your agency Records Officer to establish and maintain records, and regularly archive content that is obsolete and is not required by law or regulation.
items.field_summary: Federal records management ensures that records are identified, organized, can be found when needed, and are kept as long as necessary to support the needs of government and the public.
items.legislation_title: 44 U.S. Code, Chapter 31—Records Management by Federal Agencies
items.featured_resource_title: NARA Guidance on Managing Web Records
items.featured_resource_summary: Managing web records properly is essential to effective web site operations, especially the mitigation of the risks an agency faces by using the web to carry out agency business.

field_featured_links.title: Contact Information for Federal Agency Records Officers
field_featured_links.summary: NARA has oversight authority for the agencies and department level offices listed on these pages. The individuals listed here have authority to certify and submit records schedules to NARA.

items.field_deck: Good search functionality helps the public find exactly what they’re looking for.
items.field_summary: The search function is an essential component of any government website. It is a critical part of providing a positive user experience. Search is especially important for federal agencies which often have complex websites with large amounts of information. A well-designed search function can help users navigate this complexity and find the information they need quickly and easily.
items.legislation_title: 21st Century Integrated Digital Experience Act (21st Century IDEA) & Section III.A.4 of M-23-22

field_featured_links.title: Going Live With Search.gov
field_featured_links.summary: Your pre-launch checklist will be unique to your agency’s workflow, requirements, and deadlines. Here is a typical checklist.

field_featured_links.title: Learn how to get search engines to index the right content for better discoverability
field_featured_links.summary: Website structure and content can have a significant impact on the ability of search engines to provide a good search experience. Find all you need to know to get search right on your website.

field_featured_links.title: Special report: Search in support of federal web modernization
field_featured_links.summary: Get a high-level view of the public’s experience with seeking services and information from federal government websites that use Search.gov.

field_featured_links.title: A conversation about content audits
field_featured_links.summary: Learn why to do content audits and how to get started.

field_featured_links.title: Optimization case study: Performance, SEO, and accessibility with CFPB
field_featured_links.summary: Review some approaches that designers, developers, and analytics specialists at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau use to build search engine optimization and accessibility testing into their design and development practices.

items.field_deck: Search engine optimization (SEO) is the practice of enabling search engines to index and surface content.
items.field_summary: Strong search engine optimization (SEO) fosters transparency and enhances user experience. It empowers the public to navigate complex programs, and find the information they need quickly. Accurate and informative search results improve user experience, minimizing frustration and wasted time on irrelevant pages. Creating a search experience that directs users to the information they seek reduces reliance on contact centers and other support channels. It also saves users’ time.
items.legislation_title: 21st Century Integrated Digital Experience Act & OMB Memo M-23-22

items.field_deck: Secure websites and a secure online presence foster trust between the public and government.
items.field_summary: To protect sensitive information while maintaining access for authorized users, prioritize the implementation of security and management controls. The responsibility, however, to ensure website safety extends beyond technology. Publicly share your security protocols and establish a clear channel for users to report any suspicious activity. By making security a collaborative effort, you’ll build trust, protect sensitive information, and ensure that your website functions securely.
items.legislation_title: Federal Information Security Modernization Act of 2014 (FISMA) (Public Law 113-283) (PDF, 265 KB, 16 Pages)

items.field_deck: Use social media to effectively communicate with your audience.
items.field_summary: By using social media, agencies can strengthen their connection with the public, promote transparency, and respond to their audience’s needs. Social media meets customers where they are, and it is a great place to communicate with them — making it an essential tool for communications during emergencies.
items.legislation_title: M-10-23, Guidance for Agency Use of Third-Party Websites and Applications (PDF, 103 KB, 9 pages, June 2010)

field_featured_links.title: 6 important factors to consider for digital advertising in government
field_featured_links.summary: Learn about the benefits and potential pitfalls of digital advertising and paid media.

field_featured_links.title: Guidelines for the secure use of social media
field_featured_links.summary: Follow these guidelines from the Federal CIO Council and use social media in a manner that minimizes risk.

field_featured_links.title: How to start and sustain a federal podcast
field_featured_links.summary: Discover how to create and maintain a successful podcast at your federal agency.

field_featured_links.title: Three Tips for Using Facebook and Instagram Stories
field_featured_links.summary: See how USA.gov and USAGov en Español use stories to increase their engagement rate and number of followers as they deliver helpful information to the public.

items.field_deck: Develop websites and services that are secure, reliable, and easy to maintain.
items.field_summary: Federal websites are essential tools for unifying and communicating government information with the public in a timely manner. A well-developed website builds public trust in government and provides users with access to information when they need it. Follow up-to-date technical standards and software best practices to build accessible websites and digital services.
items.legislation_title: 21st Century IDEA) & M-23-22

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to GitHub
field_featured_links.summary: Understand how to create, manage, and publish website content in GitHub.

field_featured_links.title: Accessibility for front-end developers
field_featured_links.summary: Ensure that people with different abilities can access, understand, and navigate web content, regardless of how they’re accessing it.

field_featured_links.title: An advanced approach to accessibility
field_featured_links.summary: How to develop websites with accessibility requirements in mind.

field_featured_links.title: Technology Transformation Services (TTS) Engineering Practices Guide
field_featured_links.summary: Aim for consistency around deployments, communications, and workflows.

field_featured_links.title: U.S. Web Design System: Getting started for developers
field_featured_links.summary: Understand how to get started using the Design System by installing, compiling, and customizing code.

items.field_deck: Agreements negotiated between the federal government and vendors who offer digital tools and services.
items.field_summary: Social media is a key way that federal agencies engage with their customers and accomplish their mission. However, there are risks and legal implications associated with these tools. Be sure to coordinate with your Office of General Counsel before signing any terms of service or end-user license agreements.
items.legislation_title: M-13-10, Antideficiency Act Implications of Certain Online Terms of Service Agreements (April 4, 2013) (PDF, 1.11 MB, 17 Pages)

items.field_deck: Understand how digital services impact trust in government.
items.field_summary: Trust has to be earned every time. Federal websites and digital services can’t assume it. The guidance, resources, and community you find here will help to create government websites that inspire trust in federal digital resources.
items.legislation_title: Transforming Federal Customer Experience and Service Delivery To Rebuild Trust in Government

field_featured_links.title: Federal website standards
field_featured_links.summary: The federal website standards help agencies provide high-quality, consistent digital experiences for everyone. They cover common visual technical elements and reflect user experience best practices.

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to trust
field_featured_links.summary: Trusted digital services meet customer expectations, and they are easy to find, understand, and use. Understand how digital services impact trust in government.

field_featured_links.title: 21st Century Integrated Digital Experience Act
field_featured_links.summary: Delivering a digital-first public experience is a significant opportunity to improve the lives of millions by making it easier to access the information and services they use and count on each and every day.

field_featured_links.title: U.S. Web Design System Design principles: Earn trust
field_featured_links.summary: A list of key considerations and practical actions you can take to earn trust with users.

field_featured_links.title: Get .gov
field_featured_links.summary: Host your site on a .gov or .mil domain to assure users it’s an official government site.

field_featured_links.title: To build trust, aim for easy
field_featured_links.summary: Trust is built up with good experiences, and broken with bad ones. Build sites that build trust by considering user needs, respecting people’s time, and avoiding customer experience pitfalls.

items.field_deck: How easily and effectively people can accomplish their goals using a product or system, while having a positive experience.
items.field_summary: Usability refers to the measurement of how easily a user can accomplish their goals when using a service. This is usually measured through established research methodologies under the term “usability testing,” which includes success rates and customer satisfaction. Usability is one part of the larger user experience (UX) umbrella. While UX encompasses designing the overall experience of a product, usability focuses on the mechanics of making sure products work as well as possible for the user.
items.legislation_title: 21st Century Integrated Digital Experience Act (21st Century IDEA) and M-23-22

items.field_deck: User experience involves every interaction a user has with an agency.
items.field_summary: Websites and digital services provide better results when they are designed and delivered with the user in mind. In the current digital landscape, it is critical to adopt a user-centered approach to understand and respond to the individual needs of users. By evaluating the user experience on federal websites and digital services, agencies can increase customer satisfaction, build public trust, and reduce burden on the public.
items.legislation_title: 21st Century IDEA & M-23-22

field_featured_links.title: How to apply user experience principles and methodologies to deliver results
field_featured_links.summary: Learn from case studies and best practices from federal UX practitioners to drive innovation through inclusion.

field_featured_links.title: An introduction to design
field_featured_links.summary: Understand how and why design impacts user experience.

field_featured_links.title: DHS usability testing kit
field_featured_links.summary: Use the kit’s guidelines and templates to test the usability of your services and solutions.

field_featured_links.title: U.S. Web Design System: Design principles
field_featured_links.summary: Align on common goals and drive better user experiences on government websites.

field_featured_links.title: 18F Methods: Human-centered design tools
field_featured_links.summary: Use this collection of tools to put human-centered design into practice. They are focused on digital services, but can also be adapted to non-technical projects.
